awd_titl_txt: Collaboration to Enhance Participation of Minority and Undergraduate Students in Nuclear Science
awd_abstract_narration:
This award supports a collaborative nuclear physics research program that will further our knowledge of nuclides with high ratios of neutrons to protons, which are interesting because they exhibit behavior not observed in stable nuclides.  Experiments will be carried out at the National Superconducting Cyclotron Laboratory (NSCL) and be "day-one" ready for the upcoming Facility for Rare Isotope Beams when construction is complete.   The experiments include: investigating heavy nuclei in excited states shortly before they fragment, exploring and characterizing particular states of beryllium nuclei, measuring separation energies of excited states of magnesium, as well as research and development of a new particle detector.  Undergraduate and graduate students will collaborate with faculty at several US institutions to further this work and learn valuable highly technical skills. The projects will be evaluated through peer review and disseminated through presentations at national conferences, Ph.D. theses, and journal articles.

The PIs of this award are members of the MoNA-LISA collaboration, and the experiments they have planned will exploit the capabilities of the equipment that was developed at NSCL by the collaboration (a modular neutron array and a large area scintillation array).  Neutron-rich nuclides are very short-lived and decay by prompt neutron emission, making the MoNA-LISA system the ideal tool to investigate these nuclei.  Projects include analyzing data, implementing novel techniques to identify better and resolve isomeric nuclear states, measuring neutron-unbound states in neutron-rich nuclei, characterizing pre-fragmentation dynamics after relativistic beams interact with targets, as well as research and development toward a new gas electron multiplier based segmented target.  Future experiments focus on higher Z nuclides that are possible with the current experimental setup.  The students will learn valuable skills utilized in all facets of research including detector construction, data collection and analysis, and dissemination.

por.por_cntn:
This project focused of the study of nuclei composed of a very large number of neutrons that only exist during an extremely short amount of time (around 10-22 s). These neutron-unbound systems are found at the edge of the nuclear chart. Their detailed make-up allows to better understand how protons and neutrons interact inside the nuclear matter as well as the formation and evolution of stars. Two graduate students, six undergraduate students and four high-school students were involved and acquired nuclear physics trainings throughout the funding period by (i) participating in experiments conducted at the National Superconducting Cyclotron Laboratory (NSCL) and travelling to conferences to present their work, (ii) performing analysis of experimental data lead by the Modular Neutron Array (MoNA) Collaboration, (iii) contributing to the development of various devices to improve the detection technique and increase our knowledge of neutron-rich nuclei, and (iv) establish a unique four-way collaboration between three undergraduate institutions and one historically black college institution. The outcomes of the project on the intellectual merit include: tested a very preliminary prototype for a novel transformative detector, the Multi-layer Active target for MoNA Experiments (MAME), that houses a series of about 100-micron foils immersed in a gas volume; and performed the firsts investigations on the performances of a hybrid neutron detector that includes a plastic scintillating material and gas volume. The outcomes of the project on the broader impact include successfully conducting a pilot program designed to excite and recruit under-represented groups in nuclear physics (Physicists Inspiring the Next Generation: Exploring the Nuclear Matter [PING]) resulting in the establishment of new programs with several Minority Serving Institutions to increase participation and collaboration from these institutions with NSCL, Michigan State University and the MoNA Collaboration. Dissemination of the results from this project were done at national and international conferences as well as publications in physics journals resulting in nine invited talks, fourteen posters and three peer-reviews articles by students and faculty.
